historySlides.text: Historians believe that golf originated in Scotland in the early 1400s. For centuries, the game was played on sandy linksland in just a handful of coastal towns, most prominently St. Andrews. Early golf was principally the domain of the economic and social elite.
historySlides.title: Golf Boom Slide 1

historySlides.text: The Industrial Revolution transformed Scottish society, encouraging the rapid growth of golf. There were just 24 golf clubs in Britain in 1851 and at least 290 by 1899. The first generation of golf professionals emerged mid-century and by the 1860s were competing in elite competitions like the Open Championship.
historySlides.title: Golf Boom Slide 2

historySlides.text: Changing perspectives on female sports participation encouraged women to take up the game after 1850. The St. Andrews Ladies’ Club was formed in 1867 and played over an area known as the Himalayas. Westward Ho! (1868), Musselburgh (1872) and Carnoustie (1873) quickly followed in creating clubs and courses for women.
historySlides.title: Golf Boom Slide 3

historySlides.text: Golf’s emergence as a global game reflected the breadth of British economic interests. Golf spread to India in 1830 and Australia by 1840. Vacationers and expatriates helped extend golf across the Continent, to France in 1856, Belgium in 1888 and Italy and Switzerland by 1890. By 1895, golf proliferated in more than 35 countries.
historySlides.title: Golf Boom Slide 4

historySlides.text: Golf was played in America as early as the 1740s, but the game did not flourish in the United States until the 1880s. Many Scottish and English professionals emigrated to America to work at more than 1,000 golf courses that existed by 1900. Some became the first stars of American golf.
historySlides.title: Golf Boom Slide 5

eras_by_id.title: The Great Golf Boom
eras_by_id.description: Golf's first legends emerge as the game's popularity explodes

accomplishments.name: Golf's first professional and greenskeeper
Premier club and ball maker in St. Andrews
First player to break 80 on the Old Course in St. Andrews
Victor in numerous high-profile challenge matches
Frequent partner of Old Tom Morris
Architect of course improvements at St. Andrews and Carnoustie

profiles.bioText:
Often identified as the first golf professional in history, Allan Robertson was the first player to earn distinction as the world’s "Champion Golfer." His grandfather and father were celebrated caddies, as well as feathery ball makers and club makers of the highest repute. Allan followed in the family tradition.

Robertson famously completed in numerous high-stakes challenge matches. He took great delight in deliberately extending challenge matches to the 17th hole, when he could have polished off his foe earlier. He did so not only to avoid wounding his opponent’s pride, but also to make it impossible for the opponent to ask for better odds at their next match.
profiles.quote: He is not only the best golf player, but quite a capital ball-maker, and withall a quiet, hard-boned, wired little fellow, always as cool as a cucumber.

accomplishments.description: Morris' victories at the Open Championship included winning the 1862 Open by thirteen strokes, and a victory in 1867 at the age of 46.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the Open Championship
Premier club and ball maker in St. Andrews
Design credits include Carnoustie, Muirfield, Prestwick, and Royal Dornoch
"Keeper of the Green" in St. Andrews from 1865-1904

profiles.bioText:
Forever linked with the Old Course and St. Andrews, four-time Open Champion Tom Morris Sr. is one of the most revered figures in golf. “Old Tom” learned the game as an apprentice of Allan Robertson, caddying for him, making feather balls in Robertson’s shop, and playing with Robertson in many celebrated challenge matches.

Morris served as greenkeeper at Prestwick before returning to St. Andrews in the mid-1860s to manage the links, rebuild the greens and widen the fairways on the Old Course. He is credited as the architect of more than 75 courses throughout the British Isles. He remained a premier player for decades, last playing in the Open Championship in 1896 at age 75.
profiles.quote: One of the most remarkable men—best of men and best of golfers—that ever missed a short putt.

accomplishments.description: Morris first played in, and won, the Open Championship, at age 17.
accomplishments.name: Won four Open Championships by age 21

accomplishments.description: Morris went on to win the Claret Jug with his victory at the 1872 Open Championship
accomplishments.name: Retired the original Open Championship belt in 1870
Recorded the first hole-in-one in a major championship in 1869

profiles.bioText:
Tall, strong and handsome, Tom Morris Jr. was to golf in his era what Arnold Palmer became in the 1950s. "Golfers may come and golfers may go," wrote Harold Hutchinson, "but it is very much open to doubt whether any golfers will be quite the idol of the day as Young Tom was during his brilliant career."

He first won a professional challenge match at 13 and a professional tournament at 16. After claiming four Open Championships between 1868-1872, tragedy struck in 1875, when Morris received a telegram that his wife and baby had died during childbirth. He died three months later on Christmas Eve of a pulmonary hemorrhage, leading to speculation that he died from a broken heart.
profiles.quote: There isn't a man, English or Scotch, with the same sense of power, or golfing genius as Tommy did, the instant he addressed the ball..

accomplishments.description: Park was victorious at the Open Championship in 1860, 1863, 1866, and 1875. He added four more runner-up finishes in 1861, 1862, 1865, and 1867.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the Open Championship
Designer of at least 35 golf courses in the UK and Ireland

accomplishments.description: Park also famously won a challenge match playing his tee shots from a watch face. The watch was unscathed.
accomplishments.name: Often played challenge matches using only one hand and standing on one leg

profiles.bioText:
Celebrated as a premier club and ball maker from Musselburgh, Scotland, Willie Park Sr. staked his claim to immortality as the inaugural Open Champion in 1860. Like many professionals of his era, Park was introduced to golf as a caddie, using a whittled stick as his first club.

Tall and strong, he soon emerged as one of the most dominant golfers of his generation, gaining notoriety through his victories in challenge matches against contemporaries such as Allan Robertson, Willie Dunn and Old Tom Morris. He was a excellent putter, but it was his powerful drives that most intimidated his peers. Allan Robertson, who refused to respond to Park's public challenge in 1853, once confessed, "Willie frightens us with his long driving."
profiles.quote: He was not merely good, not merely excellent, but brilliant (as a putter). So deadly was he when within three or four yards of the hole.

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the Open Championship
Played in his first Open Championship at age 16
Author of the first book by a golf professional
Inventor of the offset putter, lob wedge, and convex-faced driver
Significantly advanced ball aerodynamics
Designed over 150 courses around the world

profiles.bioText:
Willie Park Jr. was golf's first true Renaissance men: two-time Open champion, golf equipment maker, golf writer and one of his era's finest golf course architects. The son of four-time Open Champion Willie Park, Sr., and nephew of 1870 Open Champion Mungo Park, Willie Park, Jr., was born into the "First Family of Golf." His success was often attributed to exceptional putting, perfected through twelve-hour practice sessions.

Confident, competitive and an iconoclast, Park never sought employment from a club, preferring instead to run his own business. He was an innovator in club and ball design and manufacturing, as well as golf course architecture, and parlayed his fame into business ventures that reached throughout the United Kingdom and extended to America.
profiles.quote: The Man who can putt is a match for anyone.

accomplishments.description: In the process, Ball became the first amateur, and first Englishman, to win the Open Championship.
accomplishments.name: First to with the Open and Amateur Championships in the same year
Eight-time winner of the Amateur Championship
Irish Amateur champion in 1890
Won more than 40 major amateur competitions

profiles.bioText:
A fierce competitor, known for his fiery temper and determined spirt, Englishman John Ball, Jr. dominated amateur golf in late nineteenth-century Great Britain, winning eight Amateur Championships between 1888 and 1912, the Open Championship in 1890, and the hearts and respect of his country.

Ball learned the game on the links at Holyoke, competing against his rival and friend, Harold Hilton. His swing was graceful and many contemporaries considered him the most stylish player of his era. But it was his stubbornness and dogged determination that made Ball a lion in match play. He retired with a match-play record of 99 wins against just 22 losses.
profiles.quote: I have derived greater aesthetic and emotional pleasure from watching John Ball than from any other spectacle in the game.

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the Open Championship
Four-time winner of the Amateur Championship
Two-time winner of the Irish Amateur
Winner of the 1911 U.S. Amateur Championship
First to win the Amateur and U.S. Amateur in the same year
Won over 20 major amateur competitions

profiles.bioText:
Harold Hilton, a powerful, if unconventional, shot-maker, won the Open Championship in 1892 – the first time it was played at 72 holes and contested over two days – and again in 1897. But it was his dominance of English amateur golf, and his rivalry with John Ball, Jr., that earned him widespread fame.

A wild swinger who re-gripped the club at the top of his backswing, Hilton owned a stellar match play record, boasting a 99-29 mark in amateur competitions. After retiring from competitive golf, Hilton authored several books on golf and became the founding editor of Golf Monthly and editor of Golf Illustrated.
profiles.quote: He was a small man of powerful physique; it was exhilirating to watch his perky walk between shots. His assiduity was his greatness.

accomplishments.name: Six-time winner of the Open Championship
Winner of the 1900 U.S. Open Championship
Won over 40 professional tournaments
Popularized the overlapping grip

accomplishments.description: The Vardon Trophy is awarded annually by the PGA of America to the PGA TOUR's leader in scoring average.
accomplishments.name: Namesake of the PGA TOUR's Vardon Trophy
Designer of more than 20 courses in the UK and Europe

profiles.bioText:
Harry Vardon possessed a magnetic personality, immense talent and a method so singular that he was considered a shotmaking machine. He was golf’s first international superstar, winning a record six Open Championship titles between 1896 and 1914. He toured the United States in 1900, 1913, and 1920, promoting awareness and driving growth of the game.

Vardon possessed one of the most admired and proficient golf swings the game has ever seen. He stood just 5'9" tall and tipped the scales at 155 pounds, but he had enormous hands that melted perfectly around the club. His swing was more upright and his ball flight higher than his contemporaries, giving his approach shots the advantage of greater carry and softer landing.
profiles.quote: I cannot believe that anyone ever had or will have a greater genius for hitting a golf ball than Harry Vardon.

accomplishments.name: Five-time winner of the Open Championship
Two-time winner of the British PGA Championship
Winner of the French Open, German Open, and Dutch Open
1934 Ryder Cup Captain
Co-founder and first chairman of the British Professional Golfers' Association
Specialized in designing public golf facilities

profiles.bioText:
Legendary Open champions J.H. Taylor, Harry Vardon and James Braid together dominated professional golf from the mid-1890s to the mid-1910s. Taylor earned his spot in this so-called "Great Triumvirate" by winning the Open Championship five times, becoming the first professional from England to do so.

Taylor's ability to play in wind and bad weather set him apart from his peers. He won his first Open Championship battling extreme wind and rain, while defeating Ted Ray by eight strokes. Bernard Darwin once characterized him as "a man on wires, having to choke down his temper and often suffering agonies." Beloved by many, he dedicated his later life to writing books, making clubs, and designing courses.
profiles.quote: To try to play golf really well is far from being a joke, and lightheartedness of endeavor is a sure sign of eventual failure.

accomplishments.description: Braid was also runner-up at the Open Championship four times.
accomplishments.name: Five-time winner of the Open Championship
First to break 70 in the Open Championship
Four-time News of the World Match Play champion
Co-founder of the British Professional Golfers' Association
Long-time club professional at Walton Heath

profiles.bioText:
A tall, stately man of great character who was a friend of princes, peers and the common man, James Braid was a pioneer in elevating the status of professional golfers. As a golfer, he was a late bloomer, not winning his first Open Championship until Harry Vardon and J.H. Taylor had already won three each. But once Braid won his first in 1901, there was no stopping him: He captured the Open again in 1905, 1906, 1908 and 1910, thus becoming the first man to raise the Claret Jug five times. 

Braid later turned to golf course architecture, designing or redesigning more than 200 courses, including Carnoustie, Royal Troon and the King's and Queen's courses at Gleneagles.
profiles.quote: Keep on hitting it straight until the wee ball goes in the hole.

accomplishments.description: Anderson is the only player to win three consecutive U.S. Open titles. He also finished second in 1897, at the age of 17.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the U.S. Open Championship
Four-time winner of the Western Open
Head professional at 10 different clubs

profiles.bioText:
Willie Anderson, modest in nature and never boastful of his successes, belongs in the same pantheon of U.S. Open history as Bob Jones, Ben Hogan and Jack Nicklaus. From 1897 to 1910, Anderson won the U. S. Open four times, finished second once, third once, fourth twice and fifth three times. He was, in many respects, the first dominant professional in America.

Reared on the links of North Berwick, Scotland, Anderson was a sturdy man with muscular shoulders, brawny forearms and exceptionally large hands. He played with a flat, full-sweeping action known as the "St. Andrews swing." Despite what many considered to be swing flaws, Anderson was consistently accurate. He died prematurely of arteriosclerosis at age 31.
profiles.quote: Most likely, had he lived longer, Willie would have set a record for U.S. Open championships that would never be beaten.
profiles.quoteByline: Alex Smith, 1906 and 1910 U.S. Open champion

accomplishments.name: Winner of the 1895 U.S. Amateur
Founding officer of the United States Golf Association
Founder of the Chicago Golf Club

accomplishments.description: Macdonald's design credits include the National Golf Links of America, Yale Golf Club, and Mid-Ocean Club in Bermuda.
accomplishments.name: Designer of the first 18-hole golf course in America
Author of "Scotland's Gift - Golf", a celebrated autobiography

profiles.bioText:
Charles Blair Macdonald, a "founding father" of American golf, was a driving force in the creation of the United States Golf Association in 1894. He was introduced to golf at age 16, when his parents sent him to live with his grandfather in St. Andrews, Scotland. He quickly became skilled enough to play regularly on the Old Course with two of the finest players of the day – Davey Strath and Young Tom Morris.

Several years after Macdonald returned to the United States, he designed a seven-hole course for the 1892 World's Fair in Chicago, launching a career as a world-class architect. No less an authority than Bernard Darwin accurately referred to Macdonald as the first great American golf course architect.
profiles.quote: Putting greens to a golf course are what the face is to a portrait.
